entry.title: Re: ISS - Impossible to Create a "Complementary Products"...
entry.content:
Hello there!

As per KBA 3619285 - Data Requirements for Machine Learning in Intelligent Selling services, every type of Recommendations in Intelligent Selling services have their own data requirements for machine learning model be able to work with:

Bellow are the Data requirements for each recommendation:

Trending Products

  • 10 product views or orders
  • Requires corresponding events such as add-to-cart etc.

Related Products

  • 1000 product views​
  • Requires approximately 10 page views per product.​

Personalized Products

  • 1000 product views​
  • Requires approximately 10 page views per product.​

Complementary Products

  • 50 orders ​
  • Orders need to be placed by 50 unique users and contain 50 unique products.

Replenishment Products

  • 50 orders ​
  • Orders need to be placed by 50 users and contain 50 unique products, including repeat-buy transactions done by the same user(s)​

Recently Viewed Products

  • 1 product view or more.

Kind Regards,
Wesley
SAP Technical Support

entry.title: How to update the Batch in Process and Production Orders via API?
entry.content:
Hello,

I’m working with OData APIs for order management and need to update the Batch field in orders.
When looking at the “Update Process Order” or “Update Production Order” entities, the batch field is not available.

Is there a way to update the batch on orders using APIs?
Also, is it possible to perform a mass update of the batch across components?

Best regards.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to update the Batch in Process and Production Ord...
entry.content:
Hi,

Yes, it is possible to update the Batch in both Process Orders and Production Orders, but the update must be done on the component level, not on the order header/item entities.

 

Process Orders

For process orders, you can use the entity A_ProcessOrderComponent_2 and perform a PATCH operation.
The following fields can be updated:

  • RequiredQuantity
  • StorageLocation
  • Batch (only for batches with key X – Batch Allowed or 2 – Batch Single Record)

Mass Update is also possible using the $batch endpoint with multiple change sets. Each component update requires an ETag.

You can see additional information and examples in the following link from SAP Help Portal:

  • Update Process Order

 

Production Orders

For production orders, you must use either A_ProductionOrderComponent_3 or A_ProductionOrderComponent_4, because these entities include the mandatory field ReservationRecordType.

  • A_ProductionOrderComponent_3 allows updates of RequiredQuantity, StorageLocation, and Batch.
  • A_ProductionOrderComponent_4 (RAP BO based) allows a broader set of updates (e.g., Batch, StorageLocation, Material, Plant, BaseUnit, etc.).

You can see additional information and examples in the following link from SAP Help Portal:

  • Update Production Order

Note:

  • Updates are not possible if the order status is DLT, DLFL, TECO, CLSD, or LKD.
  • Each component update requires the ETag in the If-Match header.
  • For mass processing:
           - With A_ProductionOrderComponent_3, you can change components across multiple orders in different change sets.
           - With A_ProductionOrderComponent_4, all updates in one change set must belong to the same order.

Thanks and regards.

entry.title: Change the application title on the detail page of Perform Maintenance Jobs
entry.content:
Through an adaptation project, we've made some changes to the Perform Maintenance Jobs app (F5104A). We gave the adaptation the title "<company> Perform Maintenance Jobs". Now this is what shows up at the top of the page next to our logo. This is good.

Somehow, I would have to tell our adapted tile to use the adapted target mapping for the Notification.

entry.title: Error in post on account for customer Balancing field profit Center GL line Item 1 not filled in the
entry.content:
When we are trying to post the balances for customer account using Clear incoming payments using Post on account option we are unable to post and we are not getting the profitability field to enter.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Error in post on account for customer Balancing field...
entry.content:
It is correct system behavior that error  Balancing field Profit Center in GL line item 1 not filled was issued for the posting to be made.

The profit center and segment cannot be set manually on the customer and supplier line items.

When posting occurs on account debit supplier and credit to Supplier, the system has no where to derive account assignments from.  The same principle applies with debit customer and credit customer or visa versa. 

This logic remains same in both on-premise and public cloud.

See help.sap.com documentation on document splitting  
Document Splitting https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/4911c9cc2a934a18e1000000...

See 
Examples of Business Transactions Used in Document Splitting
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/dee14b1a6c264e46b78d22d9...

Supplier Invoice (Business Transaction 0300)
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/c85faa8e702d422daacc0b6b...
here you will note that on the entry view the supplier line item has no account assignment
it is derived in the general ledger view from the expense and tax line items.

 

Where the system cannot derive an account assignment a fall back mechanism is to use a constant. However not all customers wish to use same as the system will set a fixed value for account assignment customized. You can decide whether to use it based on business requirement.
See Configuration Activity "Edit Constant for Nonassigned Processes" ID 120100.  See configuration help on same. 


I reference below KBAs for your information
2810442 - Substitutions and Document Splitting
As referenced therein: Never use substitution to set an account assignment value in one of the splitting characteristics in case you are expecting any account assignment to be populated from document splitting in that line item.

See also 

3035677 - Sum of base lines equals zero in Document Splitting
As referenced in same "A posting should only contain one business process not multiple. In case two processes are posted in a document. We recommend that you split the document. Enter a separate document for each sub-process." 

 

To create posting with additional line for profit center assignment, For example In app Create Incoming Invoice/Outgoing Invoice  you cannot directly enter a profit center with supplier/customer item, but you can control the profit center derived in the expense/revenue or balance sheet account item. 

Note it is possible to clear customer and vendor open items together 
see also KBA 2841450 - Customer and Vendor - Open items clear together which outlines the conditions and steps for same.

entry.title: Use Hana Graph Engine with Springboot
entry.content:
I'm building a Spring Boot application and considering using the SAP HANA Graph engine as graph database. I'm wondering if there’s an ORM framework, like Spring Data Neo4j, that supports direct interaction with HANA Graph.

It appears that we can model vertex and edge tables using Spring JPA, but when it comes to GraphScript, we are limited to using stored procedures. That means I have to create the procedure on the HANA instance first and then call it from the service instead of using a native query with Spring JPA for DB interaction.

Is there a more direct way to use GraphScript within SpringBoot without predefining stored procedures in HANA?

This knocks down silos, and enables anyone in the enterprise to ask questions across their enterprise and GIS data. Without middleware or ETL…

entry.title: Re: About Line Item Validation
entry.content:
Hi @ht218 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at Data Monitor, Group Reporting & KBA 3372918 - Data Monitor for more details.

To summarise, the help portal references these posting levels because they only exist in ACDOCU and not ACDOCA. Line item validation in the data monitor works on ACDOCU consolidation journal and not ACDOCA.

The validation rules do not trigger because the rules in manage substitution app only apply to ACDOCU records. They work at the time of the manual journal entry posting. The same rules are applied in the data monitor but only against consolidation records. No errors will be raised if your data does not meet the rule conditions in ACDOCU.

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Datasphere Integration with SAP S/4HANA: SAP Cloud Connector Setup Guide
entry.content:
Introduction: 

In this article, we will explore SAP Cloud Connector what it is, its purpose, and the scenarios where it becomes essential. Whether you are working with SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud or connecting SAP S/4HANA on-premise systems to the cloud, the SAP Cloud Connector plays a critical role. We will also provide a step-by-step guide on its configuration and setup, helping you seamlessly bridge your on-premise and SAP Datasphere cloud environments.

What is SAP Cloud Connector?

The SAP Cloud Connector acts as a secure link between SAP Datasphere and on-premises systems, enabling seamless integration without exposing your entire internal network (behind the firewall). It runs as an on-premises agent or middleware in a secured environment and functions as a reverse invoke proxy, providing controlled access to selected systems and resources. 

Key benefits include fine-grained control over which on-premises systems cloud applications can access, automatic recovery of broken connections, and audit logging of inbound traffic and configuration changes. It also supports high-availability setups for enterprise scenarios.

Compared to opening firewall ports or using DMZ reverse proxies, the Cloud Connector is easier and safer to deploy. It supports multiple protocols, including HTTP and RFC for native ABAP system access, and allows secure propagation of cloud user identities to on-premises systems. With simple installation, low TCO, and standard SAP support, it’s an efficient solution for connecting cloud and on-premises landscapes.

Does it support data encryption ?

Yes, TLS encryption is used for the tunnel

What are the SAP Datasphere data integration features, and in which scenarios is the SAP Cloud Connector required?

  • Replication Flows – For example, connecting to SAP ABAP CDS views and replicating data to the cloud.
  • Data Flows – For scenarios like extracting, transforming, and loading data from on-premises sources, including SAP ABAP CDS views.
  • Model Import – Importing existing ABAP CDS data models from on-premises systems into SAP Datasphere for further analytics and integration.

SAP Cloud Connector FAQs

Where can I find information about SAP Cloud Connector licensing, downloading, and installation ?

  • 2827108 - SAP Cloud Connector licensing, download and installation information.
  • It does not required separate license and it is free to use.
  • Download: SAP Cloud Connector.
  • Installation and Setup.

What are the Sizing Recommendations? 

  • Sizing for the Master Instance
  • Sizing for the Shadow Instance

What are the best practices and recommendations for setting up SAP Cloud Connector?

  • Always Use the Latest Version: Install or update to the latest Cloud Connector release to take advantage of new features and security improvements.
  • Dedicated Server Setup: Install on a dedicated server within your corporate network that has direct, unblocked access to the source system. Ideally, this server should be physically close to the source systems it connects to.
  • High Availability Setup:
    • Master (Primary Installation): Main Cloud Connector instance for normal or HA setups.
    • Shadow (Backup Installation): Secondary instance for HA, providing failover support.
  • Environment-Specific Installations: recommended to have a separate Cloud Connector for each environment (development, testing, production) to ensure stability and isolation.
  • User Configuration: Use an email ID linked to the subaccount or global account instead of an S-User for easier management.
  • Proper Sizing: Ensure the server has sufficient resources (CPU, memory, network bandwidth) to handle the expected load.
  • Regular Log Review: Continuously monitor logs and metrics to detect performance issues or connectivity problems and resolve them promptly.

SAP Cloud Connector Troubleshooting Guides:

  • Common Issues and Guided Answers.
  • Logs and Troubleshooting.
  • 3369433 - How to troubleshoot Cloud Connector related issues when creating connection in SAP Datasphere

Steps to Install, Configure and Setup the SAP Cloud Connector:

Step 1: Download, Prerequisites, and Install the Cloud Connector

Before you begin configuration, make sure the following prerequisites are in place:

  • Download: SAP Cloud Connector.
  • The Cloud Connector is installed in your on-premise network. (See Cloud Connector Installation in the SAP BTP Connectivity documentation.)
  • If you’re using egress firewalling, add these domains to the firewall/proxy allowlist:
    •  *.hanacloud.ondemand.com
    • *.k8s-hana.ondemand.com
  • You need an SAP BTP account. If you don’t already have one, create it by registering in the SAP BTP cockpit.

Step 2: Launch and Login

  • After installation, an user:Administrator account is created with the initial password: manage (case-sensitive). You’ll be prompted to change it on first login. Default/Initial login details Administrator / manage 

  • Access the Cloud Connector Administration at:
    https://<hostname>:8443 (replace <hostname> with the machine name, or use localhost if installed locally).

  • 2388242 - KBA: How to reset SAP Cloud Connector built-in user's password

Step 3: Add Your SAP BTP Subaccount

You’ll need details from your SAP Datasphere subaccount:

  • Subaccount

  • Region Host ( Data Center - Providers and Regions)

  • Sub Account User (usually the email ID tied to your BTP account)

If account info is missing, enter your SAP BTP user ID manually. For troubleshooting, see KBA: 2397165.

2571763 - Authorization problem in SAP Cloud Connector when adding Cloud Foundry subaccount

For auth errors refer Log and Trace Files: scc_core.trc

Note: Initially SAP BTP Core account details in SAP Datasphere will not be available, you must provide the SAP BTP account email and save. SAP Datasphere tenant owner can perform this.

 

 

Step 4: Verify Connection

Once the subaccount is added, the status should display Connected.

 

Step 5: Configure the Cloud Connector

For this guide, we’ll focus on Replication Flow scenarios using RFC and HTTPS protocols.

 

Step 6: Add the SAP S/4HANA (ABAP) System

  1. Select Cloud to On-Premise scenario and Back-end Type: ABAP System.

     

  2. Choose HTTPS protocol.

     

  3. Use without load balancing (application server + instance number).

     

  4. Enter your SAP S/4HANA internal host and port.

    How to find internal host and port from SAP S/4HANA ? (Run T-Code SMICM → Services).

     

  5. Leaving defaults for principal propagation and system certificate. (check your requirement and change)

     

  6. Define a virtual host name (recommended: different from the internal name).

     

     

  7. Provide a System ID (e.g., RI4) and description, then finish setup.

     

  8. Test connectivity – status should show Reachable.

     

  9. Add resources – in this scenario, we added all resources under /.

     

Step 7: Add RFC Protocol Resources

  1. Select RFC protocol.

     

  2. Enter system mapping details (System ID + description).

     

  3. Finish setup and test connectivity.

     

      

  4. Map required resources:

     

    • With Prefix (e.g., DHAMB_)

        

    • With Exact Name (e.g., RFC_FUNCTION_SEARCH)

       

  5. Ensure the status turns Green for all resources.

     

Step 8: Maintain IP Allow list in SAP Datasphere

  1. Identify the public IP address of the host where Cloud Connector is installed (e.g., via whatismyip.com or ip.me or whatever way you are aware of).

     

  2. Add this IP under Trusted Cloud Connector IPs in SAP Datasphere:
    System → Configuration → IP Allowlist.

     

Step 9: Maintain the Cloud Connector Location ID in SAP Datasphere

Go to:
SAP Datasphere →System → Administration → Data Source Configuration and maintain the Cloud Connector Location ID.

 

 

With these steps completed, your SAP Cloud Connector is successfully installed, connected, and configured to integrate and create a native connection type of SAP S/4HANA on-premise with SAP Datasphere.

Summary: 

In this blog, we saw how the SAP Cloud Connector helps connect SAP Datasphere with on-premise systems in a secure and easy way. It supports features like Replication Flows, Data Flows, and Model Import for smooth data integration. We also looked at the benefits such as simple setup, better security, high availability, and low cost. With best practices like keeping it updated, using a dedicated server, and regular monitoring, you can ensure reliable performance. Finally, we walked through the step-by-step setup to successfully link SAP S/4HANA with SAP Datasphere.

entry.content:

I need to understand why the gas contract causes this reduction in the net value and, more importantly, how to adjust it to behave like the energy contract.

entry.title: 5 pontos essenciais para o fechamento da fase EXPLORE em projetos SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
entry.content:
A fase EXPLORE da metodologia SAP Activate é o coração do projeto: é nela que os processos são validados com base no Fit-to-Standard e que os requisitos de negócio ganham forma dentro da solução.
Encerrar bem esta etapa é fundamental para avançar ao REALIZE com confiança, sem lacunas que possam comprometer o desenvolvimento, os testes e, no futuro, o Go-Live.

O Roadmap da metodologia SAP Activate apresenta informações bem completas para apoio nesse momento. Mas caso precise de um guia para referência rápida, deixo abaixo os 5 pontos chave que devem ser considerados neste momento. Como mais referências, deixo ao final deste post o link para o Roadmap completo.

A seguir, compartilho os 5 pontos-chave que devem ser observados no fechamento da fase EXPLORE:

1. Conclusão dos Workshops Fit-to-Standard

Todos os workshops planejados devem estar concluídos, com documentação aprovada e feedback dos Key Users.

  • Processos confirmados e gaps documentados

  • Decisões de design registradas

  • Escopo validado junto às áreas de negócio

Sem isso, corre-se o risco de avançar para o REALIZE com requisitos ainda abertos.

 

2. Backlog de Requisitos Formalizado

Os requisitos adicionais identificados (extensões, integrações, relatórios, formulários) precisam estar registrados em backlog estruturado.

  • Itens priorizados (MoSCoW ou outro critério definido)

  • Histórias de usuário/documentação clara

  • Aprovação dos responsáveis de negócio

Isso garante visibilidade do que será entregue e do que pode ser postergado.

3. Estratégia de Dados Validada

O plano de dados deve estar claro e acordado entre cliente e integrador.

  • Definição de objetos de dados mestres e transacionais

  • Estratégia de limpeza, extração e carga (ETL)

  • Regras de qualidade e responsáveis definidos

Avançar sem clareza nesse ponto gera grandes riscos no REALIZE e no Deploy.

4. Plano de Testes Estruturado

Antes de encerrar o EXPLORE, deve haver um plano de testes robusto.

  • Estratégia de testes unitários, integrados e UAT

  • Identificação de cenários de negócio críticos

  • Papéis e responsabilidades definidos (quem testa o quê)

Assim, os testes no REALIZE fluem com mais organização e eficiência.

5. Riscos, Decisões e Governança Atualizados

Todos os riscos, dependências e decisões-chave discutidos no EXPLORE precisam estar formalmente registrados.

  • Riscos com planos de mitigação

  • Matriz de decisões e impactos documentados

  • Governança validada para seguir acompanhando no REALIZE

Essa visibilidade fortalece a confiança da liderança e reduz surpresas adiante.

Conclusão

Encerrar bem o EXPLORE significa ter: processos validados, backlog estruturado, dados planejados, testes organizados e governança atualizada.
Com esses pilares, o projeto entra no REALIZE com solidez, permitindo foco total na construção, testes e preparação para o Go-Live com muito mais previsibilidade e segurança.

O resultado? Um projeto mais ágil, sustentável e alinhado ao valor de negócio esperado com o SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

Link para o Roadmap SAP Activate relacionado a esta etapa:

https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer/group/658F507A-D6F5-4B78-9EE1-0300C5F1E40F/roadmapcontentpage/a11ec6d657054bf9:FA163EAF25B21EEB8FC47DE9E728A8DB

entry.title: 5 Essential Points for Successfully Closing EXPLORE in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Projects
entry.content:
The EXPLORE phase in the SAP Activate methodology is the heart of the project: it is where business processes are validated through Fit-to-Standard workshops and where requirements take shape within the solution.

Closing this phase properly is critical to move into REALIZE with confidence, without gaps that could compromise build, testing, and ultimately the Go-Live.

The SAP Activate Methodology Roadmap provides comprehensive information to support this stage. However, if you need a quick reference guide, below are the 5 key points that should be considered at this moment. For additional references, I’ve included at the end of this post the link to the full Roadmap.

1. Completion of Fit-to-Standard Workshops

All planned workshops must be completed, with documentation approved and feedback captured from Key Users.

  • End-to-end processes validated and confirmed

  • Identified gaps fully documented

  • Design decisions captured and signed off

Without this, the project risks moving into REALIZE with open requirements and unclear scope.

2. Requirements Backlog Formalized

All additional requirements (extensions, integrations, reports, forms) need to be consolidated into a structured backlog.

  • Prioritized items (using MoSCoW or similar prioritization criteria)

  • Clear user stories or requirement documentation

  • Approval from business stakeholders

This ensures transparency on what will be delivered now and what might be deferred.

3. Data Strategy Validated

The data approach must be clear and agreed upon between customer and implementation partner.

  • Scope of master and transactional data defined

  • Extraction, transformation, and load (ETL) strategy confirmed

  • Data quality rules and ownership assigned

Uncertainty here leads to major risks later in REALIZE and DEPLOY.

4. Test Strategy Established

Before closing EXPLORE, a solid test strategy should be in place.

  • Plan covering unit, integration, and user acceptance testing (UAT)

  • Identification of critical business scenarios

  • Clear ownership of who executes each testing activity

This sets the foundation for smooth and efficient testing during REALIZE.

5. Risks, Decisions, and Governance Updated

All risks, dependencies, and key decisions discussed during EXPLORE must be formally tracked.

  • Updated risk register with mitigation plans

  • Decision log maintained and approved

  • Governance structure validated for the next phase

Conclusion

Successfully closing EXPLORE means having: validated processes, a structured backlog, a defined data strategy, a solid test plan, and updated governance and risk management.
With these foundations, the project can enter REALIZE with stability and focus, enabling the team to dedicate full energy to build, testing, and preparation for Go-Live with confidence.

The result? A project that is more agile, sustainable, and aligned to business value with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

Link to the SAP Activate Roadmap related to this phase:

https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer/group/658F507A-D6F5-4B78-9EE1-0300C5F1E40F/roadmapcontentpage/a11ec6d657054bf9:FA163EAF25B21EEB8FC47DE9E728A8DB

entry.title: Re: How to Deactivate fiori app's in Business roles in SA...
entry.content:
Hello @pranaytejak 

Apps can be deactivated in a business role only if the business catalogue assigned indicates “Supports IAM Applications is Yes.” Use Maintain Business Roles → IAM Apps to turn these options on or off. SAP Help: How to Activate or Deactivate IAM Apps of Type App Authorisation Variant

If a catalogue indicates “Supports IAM Apps is No,” you cannot deactivate individual apps. Instead, remove the catalogue from the role and assign a custom business catalogue that includes only the apps you need in CO11N, but not in CO13, through Custom Catalogue Extensions. SAP Support Portal-3582147 - How to remove an application from a Business Catalogue

Note: You cannot delete apps from an SAP-delivered business catalogue; they can only be deactivated at the role level within IAM-supported catalogues.

Hiding tiles in Spaces/Pages affects only the UI and doesn’t remove authorisation. Users can still access them through search or URL if the catalogue stays active. For actual restrictions, use catalogues and roles. SAP Community

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Posted to Stock field in Create Physical Inventory do...
entry.content:
Hello @MT1208 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at KBA 3580792 & Migrate Data Using Staging Tables  for more details.

In summary, the Posted to stock field is mandatory in certain migration objects for example material stocks. Unfortunately, you cannot remove or deactivate this field in the public cloud. This is simply because migration templates cannot be changed. However, you do have some options to play with it:

You can populate the field with consistent value such as YES if you want the stock immediately posted or NO if you want only the balance migrated without posting.

If the field does not apply to your described scenario, you can use NO in migration and later adjust stock by using normal goods movement or inventory upload transactions.

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: not able to escape the approval
entry.content:
Hi @jerrysam 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at Approval Workflows for Sales Documents, Manage Sales Document Workflows & Manage Teams and Responsibilities for more details.

In summary, based on your description, it seems that a workflow instance was already triggered or another approval scenario you have created is still active.

  • First you need to identify which approval is still active or which one was already triggered. To do this, open my Inbox or the workflow instance app to see if a workflow is running for the sales order and which approver it is assigned to.
  • Check the manage teams and responsibilities functionality for sales document approval responsibilities. If this rule is still defined, the system can still trigger standard approval workflows.
  • Review your configure workflow scenarios in CBC to confirm that no active scenario is linked to sales returns.
  • You can also completely bypass workflow approvals for return by ensuring both workflow definitions and responsibility management rules are disabled or removed.

If the workflow instance has already been triggered, you either approve or reject ist from My Inbox or you can cancel the workflow instance through Workflow Administration.

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP WM Public cloud storage bin Capacity check planning for putway.
entry.content:
Could you please explain how capacity planning functions in warehouse management within SAP Public Cloud?


The client’s requirement involves handling two types of storage bins:



  • Storage bin with a capacity of 1.0 TO



  • Storage bin with a capacity of 1.5 TO



There is a material called SS wire roll, which is procured from different suppliers and varies in weight. Using batch-specific units of measure during synchronous goods receipt, the process is as follows:



  • Material with a weight less than or equal to 1.0 TO should be placed in a 1.0 TO bin.



  • Material with a weight greater than 1.0 TO but less than or equal to 1.5 TO should be stored in a 1.5 TO bin



Additionally, if all 1.0 TO bins are full, materials weighing less than or equal to 1.0 TO may need to be placed in a 1.5 TO bin, with up to 4 quantities per bin depending on their size.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Create Outbound delivery in WM without stock (Public...
entry.content:
Thank you for your question.

Have a look at Creating and Processing Outbound Deliveries, Create Outbound Deliveries – From Sales Orders, https://help.sap.com/doc/b3bae8ac944b45d796409ea3580bef4b/2508.00/en-US/WN_CE2508_EN.pdf,  https://help.sap.com/doc/7c9e0bbbd1664c2581b2038a1c7ae4b3/2508.500/en-US/FSD_CE2508.pdf for more details.

In summary, the grouping of multiple sales order into a single outbound delivery is supported in public cloud but not through VGM1, VG01 as you know it from ECC. However what is possible is:

  • To use the Create Outbound Deliveries from Sales Orders or Run Outbound Delivery Creation apps.
  • While doing that, make sure your sales orders meet the delivery consolidation criteria such as shipping point, delivery date, etc. The system will then automatically create a single delivery.
  • Please note that the system will only include the confirmed quantities if aATP is active. Picking tasks are created for available stock and you can add subsequent stock to the same delivery as it becomes available without using negative stock.

Running a delivery consolidation in batch jobs rather than manual grouping is the recommended public cloud approach.

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to Trigger Service Contract Outputs Based on Custom Fields
entry.content:
Introduction

In this blog, we are going to explain how to trigger service contract output based on your custom fields in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. We will also offer some tips that some of our customers faced. In summary, there're three steps to achieve the purpose:

  1. Define custom fields
  2. Configure output management
  3. Generate outputs for service contracts

Now let's see how to implement this in your system step by step. 

1. Define Custom Fields

Business role: Extensibility Specialist or Administrator.

App: Custom Fields.

1) Create a new custom field

In our case, we create a new checkbox field and name it CTU4_Output_Test. Use the Service Header business context.

2) Enable usage for relevant CDS views

We need to enable usage for the following two CDS views:

  • C_SRVCCONTROUTPUTPARAM Service Contract Output Parameter Determination
  • I_SERVICEDOCUMENT Service Transaction: You must enable the usage of this CDS view. Otherwise, the function may not work.

3) Save and publish the new custom field

2. Configure output management

Business role: Administrator

App: Output Parameter Determination

1) Go to the Output Parameter Determination app

Select the "Service Contract" business rules and the "Email Settings" determination step.

Tip: You must right click around Show Rules for Service Contract to see a popup that you can choose "Refresh Condition Parameters of Application". After this step, you can later see the custom fields that you recently published for outputs.

Then you confirm the refresh.

 

2) Edit decision table

Click on Edit to maintain business rules. To adjust condition columns, we use the Table Settings menu. The system currently shows the default setting.

 

3) Maintain table settings

  • Choose "From Context Data Objects.." to associate your custom field.

     

  • Choose the condition parameter CTU4_Output_Test that you created in Step 1.

     

4) Define the condition

For our custom field CTU4_Output_Test, since it's a boolean checkbox, you can choose X condition. Then we define the sender email and choose an email template.

 

5) Check the business rules and activate it

3. Create service contract output

Business role: Customer Service Manager

App: Manage Service Contracts

Create a service contract in the Manage Service Contracts app. Go to the Ouput Items assignement block. Tick the checkbox CTU4_Output_Test to see that the email template is displayed. When you save the service contract, the output is sent automatically.

 

Conclusion

In this blog, we explained how to define a custom field, configure output management, and generate the output. This is very helpful when you want the system to send outputs to target recipients, for example to your customers about the contract change. Please try this function in your system and let us know if it helps! If you have any questions, feel free to comment this blog or ask a question.

Additional Information

You can find more details about output management in this instruction: Setting Up Output Management.

entry.title: Re: Signavio and Enable Now integration
entry.content:
Hi Pawel,

The error message is definitely indicating that an object that has been attached to one of the Signavio activity objects is not published.  Please ensure that:

1. All object are published - please unpublish the relevant objects in Manager and publish then again, just to be sure
2. You have attached only one object, per language, to each Signavio activity object
3. You have definitely created the two custom attributes against each Signavio object in the corresponding Signavio Workspace - the first step of the integration process.

If all these things have been done and you still get the error, please raise a support ticket using the Component ID KM-SEN-PRO and get support to take a detailed look at the issue.

Regards
Shane

entry.title: Re: Widget is visible in ppt export even when made invisible
entry.content:
Recommended Solution Path (Short-Term)

If your goal is minimizing maintenance overhead and getting clean export:

  1. Create a "Print Page" inside the same story (not a new story)

  2. Put only the export-worthy widgets on this page

  3. Use a button to navigate to this page

  4. Export this page only to PPT

This keeps everything within the same story while giving you control over export content.

entry.title: Automating Document Attachment in ME21N Using MIME Repository
entry.content:
Requirement/Introduction :

We need to attach few pdf with all the po's with specific doctype and companycode , further it will be sent to respective user after releasing from me29n. For sending attach GOS over mail after releasing from me29n is already there we just need to attach the gos to newly created po's which will be stored in MIME Repository folder (SE80).

Main Part/ Implementation :

Step 1: PDFs in MIME Repository

  Go to T-Code SE80

  1. Navigate to the MIME Repository tab
  2. Expand the path: SAP → PUBLIC
  3. Create a folder (e.g., /SANKET/)
  4. ADD PDF files into this folder

Step 2: Implemention

  •  Find Enhancement Spot(BADI) (SE18)
  •  Check BADI : me_process_po_cust Is Implemented / Not.
  •  If Implemented then then do changes regarding this requirment in Method ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST~POST   because it will called when ever you will save po in me21n. 
  • Else you need to Implemented the badi in z/y Implementation first with this changes and all conditions.

Step 3: Logic in ME21N Save Event

ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST~POST This logic triggers after the PO is saved in ME21N.

" -   -   -Trigger logic only during ME21N
IF sy-tcode = 'ME21N'.
DATA: lv_folder     TYPE string,
      lo_mime_api   TYPE REF TO if_mr_api,
      lt_file_list  TYPE string_table,
      lv_mime_path  TYPE string,
      lv_xstring    TYPE xstring,
      lv_objlen     TYPE i,
      lt_solix      TYPE solix_tab,
      lt_obj_cont   TYPE soli_tab,
      lt_obj_head   TYPE TABLE OF soli,
      ls_obj_head   TYPE soli,
      ls_hd_dat     TYPE sood1,
      ls_fol_id     TYPE soodk,
      ls_doc_id     TYPE soodk,
      ls_object     TYPE borident,
      ls_new_fm_dat TYPE sofm2,
      ls_new_hd_dat TYPE sood2,
      ls_note       TYPE borident,
      ls_folmem_k   TYPE sofmk,
      lv_ep_note    TYPE borident-objkey,
      lv_filename   TYPE string,
      lv_extension  TYPE string.

  
" -  -  - Define MIME folder path
  lv_folder       = '/SAP/PUBLIC/SANKET/'.

  " - -  -  Get reference to MIME Repository API
  CALL METHOD cl_mime_repository_api=>if_mr_api~get_api
    RECEIVING r_mr_api = lo_mime_api.

  " - - - Fetch list of files from MIME folder
  CALL METHOD lo_mime_api->file_list
    EXPORTING i_url = lv_folder
    IMPORTING e_files = lt_file_list
    EXCEPTIONS OTHERS = 1.

  " - - - Loop through each file in the MIME folder
  LOOP AT lt_file_list INTO lv_mime_path.
    " - - - Get MIME API instance
    CALL METHOD cl_mime_repository_api=>get_api
      RECEIVING r_mr_api = DATA(lo_mime_repo).

    " - - - Read file content as xstring
    CALL METHOD lo_mime_repo->get
      EXPORTING i_url = lv_mime_path
      IMPORTING e_content = lv_xstring
      EXCEPTIONS OTHERS = 1.





" - - - Get SAPOffice root folder ID
    CALL FUNCTION 'SO_FOLDER_ROOT_ID_GET'
      EXPORTING region = 'B'
      IMPORTING folder_id = ls_fol_id.

    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      MESSAGE 'Failed to read PDF from MIME repository' TYPE 'E'.
      RETURN.
    ENDIF.

    " - - - Convert xstring to binary format
    CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_XSTRING_TO_BINARY'
      EXPORTING buffer = lv_xstring
      IMPORTING output_length = lv_objlen
      TABLES binary_tab = lt_solix.

    " Convert binary to SOLITAB format
    CALL FUNCTION 'SO_SOLIXTAB_TO_SOLITAB'
      EXPORTING ip_solixtab = lt_solix
      IMPORTING ep_solitab = lt_obj_cont.

    " Extract filename and extension
    SPLIT lv_mime_path AT '/' INTO TABLE DATA(lt_parts).
    READ TABLE lt_parts INDEX lines(lt_parts) INTO DATA(lv_fullname).
    SPLIT lv_fullname AT '.' INTO lv_filename lv_extension.

    " Prepare document header metadata
    ls_hd_dat-objdes   = lv_filename.
    ls_hd_dat-objlen   = lv_objlen.
    ls_hd_dat-objpri   = '5'.
    ls_hd_dat-file_ext = lv_extension.

    " - - - Prepare object header lines
    CONCATENATE '&SO_FILENAME=' lv_filename '.' lv_extension INTO ls_obj_head-line.
    APPEND ls_obj_head TO lt_obj_head.
    APPEND VALUE #( line = |&SO_FORMAT=BIN| ) TO lt_obj_head.

    " - - - Insert document into SAPOffice
    CALL FUNCTION 'SO_OBJECT_INSERT'
      EXPORTING
        folder_id         = ls_fol_id
        object_hd_change  = ls_hd_dat
        object_type       = 'EXT'
        owner             = sy-uname
      IMPORTING
        object_id         = ls_doc_id
        object_fl_display = ls_new_fm_dat
        object_hd_display = ls_new_hd_dat
      TABLES
        objcont           = lt_obj_cont
        objhead           = lt_obj_head.

    " - - - Prepare PO object reference
    ls_object-objtype = 'BUS2012'.
    ls_object-objkey  = ls_mepoheader-ebeln.

    " - - - Get logical system ID
    SELECT SINGLE logsys INTO ls_object-logsys FROM t000 WHERE mandt = sy-mandt.

    " - - - Prepare folder/document linking structure
    ls_folmem_k-foltp = ls_fol_id-objtp.
    ls_folmem_k-folyr = ls_fol_id-objyr.
    ls_folmem_k-folno = ls_fol_id-objno.
    ls_folmem_k-doctp = ls_doc_id-objtp.
    ls_folmem_k-docyr = ls_doc_id-objyr.
    ls_folmem_k-docno = ls_doc_id-objno.

    " - - -  Prepare MESSAGE object for linking
    lv_ep_note      = ls_folmem_k.
    ls_note-objtype = 'MESSAGE'.
    ls_note-logsys  = ls_object-logsys.
    ls_note-objkey  = lv_ep_note.

    " Create attachment link between PO and document
    CALL FUNCTION 'BINARY_RELATION_CREATE_COMMIT'
      EXPORTING
        obj_rolea    = ls_object
        obj_roleb    = ls_note
        relationtype = 'ATTA'
      EXCEPTIONS
        OTHERS       = 1.
  ENDLOOP.
ENDIF.

Conclusion:

Here we have create a folder in mime reporistory(SE80) which will contain all the files which we need as attachments in newly created po's(purchase orders) , then we will implement badi (me_process_po_cust) post method and do the required changes as per guided above and we have implemented the enhancement which will attach documents from mime reposritory to po when ever we create new po.

entry.content:

entry.title: PY-ID: Full Salary Payout on TER Tax Method (Gross-Up Income)
entry.content:
The article "Penghitungan TER: Mau Terima Gaji Utuh? Di-Gross Up Saja" (TER Calculation: Want to receive your full salary? Just Gross it Up)" on DJP website starts by acknowledging a widely held belief about the new TER tax method - that it has made monthly personal income tax higher. I admit that I also fell into this trap, as my monthly tax calculation seemed higher than it was under the previous method. However, as the article confirms, the year-end calculation will adjust the tax to equal the old method's result.

From the article, The interesting word is "Di-Gross Up Saja" (Just Gross it Up) and how it work in our payroll solution. Start from the keyword meaning first.

Gross Income: The tax on this income is borne by employee.

Gross-Up Income: The tax on this income is paid by employer. In other words, the company guarantees to pay a specific net salary to the employee, which is referred to as the Guaranteed Net Amount (GNA) in our payroll solution.

To provide a clearer understanding, let's use an example from a previous article.

Example: Mr. A, a permanent employee at Company XYZ, has a monthly salary of IDR30,000,000.00 in 2025. He is single with no dependents, which corresponds to the PTKP TK/0 status.

In the payroll log, you'll see the tax method is "TER". The TER Type is determined by the employee's PTKP status and is categorized as A, B, or C. Based on his status, Mr. A would fall under TER Type A (also known as the TER Tax Table A), and his specific tax rate will be based on which salary range in that table his monthly income falls into. Since this is a gross income, the tax amount will be borne by the employee.

Now, what changes if we designate the monthly salary of IDR30,000,000.00 as a Guaranteed Net Amount (GNA) paid by the company? The key change is the tax burden shifts from the employee to the employer and employee receive full salary IDR30,000,000.00. The employer must perform a Gross-Up calculation to determine the additional tax they need to pay on the employee's behalf.

To find the Gross-Up amount, we start with the Guaranteed Net Amount (GNA). We then iteratively add an amount on top of the GNA and calculate the tax on that new total. We continue this process until the additional amount equals the tax on the total income. This final total addition is the Gross-Up amount, or the amount the company pays on the employee's behalf to cover the tax.

From the example:

  • Guaranteed Net Amount (GNA) = Monthly Salary IDR30,000,000.00
  • Iteratively added amount = Tax amount.

Note: Please be careful to configure the added amount correctly by confirming customer's requirements to ensure a shared understanding of the agreement between the employer and employee. If the employer agrees to cover any other amounts, these must also be included in the configuration. Failure to do so may be the reason the result does not meet the requirements, and it could take a long time to identify the issue.

Deduction Paid by Employer for Guaranteed Net Amount (V_T541A) is a configuration table for added amount. You can set your own Type of Guaranteed Net Amount by adding the payroll wagetype in the table.

From the picture, this is the Guaranteed Net Amount Type (GNA Type) "03", which adds only the regular tax amount in each Gross-Up iteration. It is a configuration fit for the example.

Guaranteed Net Amounts table (V_T541N) is a configuration table for Guaranteed Net Amount and Deduction Wage Type. For a full understanding of the standard wage type we provide for TER tax method, please refer to the following  KBA3459100. 

With this configuration, you can run a Gross-Up case and pay the guaranteed full salary to your employees. This setup is for non-fluctuating salaries. In the real world, a salary may increase or decrease in the mid-year, which would affect the tax result. If the salary decreases, the tax amount will also decrease because total income is reduced. Under TER tax method, taxes are calculated on a monthly basis, based on the income received date, with a final adjustment only made the end of the year or the last tax period.

Example: Mr. B, a permanent employee at Company XYZ, has a monthly salary of IDR50,000,000.00 for January and February of 2025 and IDR20,000,000 for the remainder of the year. He is single with no dependents, which corresponds to the PTKP TK/0 status.

Based on this case, it's likely that the final annual tax calculation will be less than the total cumulative tax paid from January to December. This difference shows that the employee has overpaid their tax and can claim a tax refund from the government.

Yes, that is correct. This conclusion applies if the case is a Gross Income type, not a Gross-Up income type. In a Gross-Up income type, you need to calculate the Gross-Up amount first to guarantee net amount for the employee. In this case, if you check the Gross-Up function in the payroll log, you will find a negative deduction amount at step 0. This is an incorrect input for the Gross-Up function.

 

Note: To correct the Gross-Up function due to a negative deduction amount at step 0, I have suggested implementing a BAdI on this KBA2252783 to clear negative deduction amount at step 0 and set your own special rule value from BAdI in Deduction Paid by Employer for Guaranteed Net Amount (V_T541A) to call your BAdI in the Gross-Up iteration.

entry.title: Alerts for Employee's Dependent Information
entry.content:
Requirement:

There is a company policy linked to certain benefits like educational allowances or compensatory benefits, given to the employees in case any of the dependents of the employee is a student in a given country. Hence, the customer needs to capture these details with respect to each of the dependents to track the duration of their student status for benefits and eligibility purpose. Also, the customer wants to trigger alerts/emails to the employee if the details are expiring, so that timely actions can be taken to extend the same.

Challenge:

Although we can create custom fields to capture the information, we cannot trigger alerts based on the Dependents Portlet. This is a system limitation. Hence, we had to work on a custom solution to achieve the requirement.

Solution Approach:

To overcome the limitation of the Dependent Portlet Alerts, we explored the possibility of generating alert via custom MDF. However, we cannot replace the standard dependents portlet altogether as there are other dependencies like Benefits Enrollment, Time Off Balance Calculation etc. which are all referenced from this portlet and replacing this will have an impact on all these functionalities. Given this, we aligned to work with custom MDF to have the data captured from the dependent portlet in the backend to generate the relevant alerts.

The overall solution provided to this requirement can be segregated into three parts:

Part 1: Enabling the fields and custom object creation to capture the student details of the dependent.

Part 2: Auto-updating the custom object with the latest dependent details captured on the Dependent Information Portlet

Part 3: Generating the Alert related to the expiry of the student details of the dependent.

Let's deep dive into each of these parts now:

Part 1: Enabling the fields and custom object creation to capture the student details of the dependent

Custom fields are created on the Global Information Portlet - Country specific element for Dependents to capture the student details. The information captured in our case includes the below fields, this may differ from customer to customer based on the requirement.

  • Creation of the Custom Object to capture the details from Dependent's Information:
    • Parent - Child Custom Objects are created with external code of Parent Object as User and external code of the child object as String.
    • Child Object will capture the details for each of the dependent's separately as there could be multiple dependents who are student, each having different details leading to different alerts.
    • Since, the dependent's portlet is an effective dated portlet, hence, we have created the custom object as well to be effective dated.
    • The Custom Object will not be enabled on the employee profile.
    • Below is the configuration of the Parent and Child Object-

Parent Object:

Child Object:

Part 2: Auto-updating the custom object with the latest dependent details captured on the Dependent Information Portlet

  • To achieve this, we have utilized integration center and have scheduled interfaces to pick the latest data from the Dependent's Portlet and update the custom object created.
  • As there is a limitation of the Integration Center that it cannot create multiple child objects in one go, we went ahead with two integrations - first integration creates the placeholder for the parent object and second integration to create the dependents information as multiple child records.
  • The scheduling of the interfaces is done accordingly.

The configuration of the first interface:

The configuration of the second interface:

Part 3: Generating the Alert related to the expiry of the student details of the dependent

  • Alert Message is created

  • Alert rule is created with the base object as the parent object to compare the dates and create the alert 3 months prior to student end date.

  • Apply the rule on the parent object as a post save rule.

With this, once the integration runs, it updates the custom object with the latest Dependent's information and based on this information, the alert message is created, updated in case of any changes and pending alerts are deleted in case the dependent's information is deleted.

Alert triggered to employee 3 months before the student end date.

Conclusion:

Using this approach, we have achieved the custom requirement which is not available by standard offering of SuccessFactors. This solution approach is fully scalable for any additional similar requirements for the portlet for which the standard alert functionality is not available as well.

entry.title: Creation of Value Range in Business Rule Framework Plus(BRF+)
entry.content:
In Business Rule Framework plus (BRF+), a Value Range refers to an expression used to check if a specific value falls within a defined range or set of values. The outcome of a value range expression is always a Boolean (true or false), indicating whether the value meets the specified range condition.

Steps to create Value range in BRF+ .

Right click on application and followed with image attached. 

Provide name, short description and click on create and navigate to object.  

Create a data object of date and add in the condition and provide the condition if the input  date is equal to fixed date and result will be displayed in true or false .

Save and activate . Now click on start stimulation and in next screen click on continue. 

 

Select the date and click on execute . 

If the selected date is in range it will be true 

 Select the date and click on execute . 

If the selected date is not in the range it will be false 

Conclusion:

  • Flexibility in Definition:
    BRF+ offers the flexibility to define value ranges explicitly as reusable expressions or implicitly directly within other expressions like decision tables. The choice between explicit and implicit ranges depends on the need for reusability across different parts of a BRF+ application.
  • Boolean Result:
    Value range expressions in BRF+ always yield a Boolean result, returning true if the tested value lies within the defined range and false otherwise. This makes them suitable for use in conditions within decision tables, loops, or other expressions that require a true/false evaluation.
  • Support for Various Operators and Types:
    BRF+ value ranges support various comparison operators (e.g., equals, not equals, greater than, less than, between) and can be applied to different data types, including numeric values, text, and dates. This allows for comprehensive and precise rule modeling.
  • Enhancing Decision Logic:
    Value ranges are crucial for building robust decision logic in BRF+. They enable the creation of rules that categorize or process data based on specific thresholds, intervals, or sets of allowed values, thereby automating and streamlining business processes.
  • Impact on Performance and Maintainability:
    While implicit ranges offer quick implementation for ad-hoc conditions, explicit, reusable value range expressions contribute to better performance and maintainability in complex BRF+ applications by promoting consistency and reducing redundancy in rule definitions.
  • Limitations and Workarounds:
    There can be limitations, such as the number of entries in a single decision table cell when defining ranges or sets of values. Workarounds, like using patterns or grouping properties, may be necessary to overcome such limitations and effectively model complex business rules.

entry.title: Validations in BOPF and Consistency Validation in BOPF
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

In this blog we will be going to learn about the Validations in BOPF.

What is Validation in BOPF? 

In BOPF, a validation is a consistency check defined on a node of the business object that ensures the data fulfills specific business rules before it is saved or processed. 

In BOPF, keeping the data clean and consistent is very important. Validations help achieve this by checking the data against specific rules. Just like determinations, validations are created on the node of the data model where they are needed. Today, we’ll walk you through how to create a validation and write the logic for it in the implementation class. 

Procedure  

Here we are defining a custom Travel table (zkk_dt_travel). 

@EndUserText.label : 'Data base table for Travel Details'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #EXTENSIBLE_ANY
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table zkk_dt_travel {

  key client     : abap.clnt not null;
  key travel_id  : zkk_de_travel_id not null;
  key user_email : zkk_de_email not null;
  start_date     : dats;
  destination    : zkk_de_destination;
  status         : zkk_de_status;
  expense_type   : zkk_de_item_type;
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode : 'zkk_travel_hdr.curr_key'
  total_cost     : zkk_de_cost;
  curr_key       : zkk_de_cost_key;
  remarks        : zkk_de_remarks;
  created_by     : zkk_de_createdby;
  created_on     : datum;

}

The above table has the below shown data.

For the Database table we are defining the Basic view  

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZKK_DBV_TRAVEL'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Interface view for Travel details'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true


@ObjectModel:{
modelCategory: #BUSINESS_OBJECT,
compositionRoot: true,
transactionalProcessingEnabled: true,
writeActivePersistence: 'ZKK_dt_travel',

createEnabled: true,
updateEnabled: true,
deleteEnabled: true
}

@OData.publish: true
define view zi_kk_travel
  as select from zkk_dt_travel
{
  key travel_id,
      @ObjectModel.mandatory: true
  key user_email,
      start_date,
      destination,
      status,
      @ObjectModel.mandatory: true
      expense_type,
      @ObjectModel.mandatory: true
      total_cost,
      curr_key,
      remarks,
      created_by,
      created_on
}

For creating the Business object directly from the Eclipse editor, we have to make use of annotations which I have given with their functionality 

Here’s the explanation of each annotation in your snippet: 

@ObjectModel: { 
 modelCategory: #BUSINESS_OBJECT, 
 compositionRoot: true, 
 transactionalProcessingEnabled: true, 
 writeActivePersistence: 'ZKK_dt_travel', 
 
 createEnabled: true, 
 updateEnabled: true, 
 deleteEnabled: true 
} 
 Explanation 

modelCategory: #BUSINESS_OBJECT 

  • Declares that the CDS view represents a Business Object (BO). This means it can be used in BOPF to handle business logic and transactional operations. 

compositionRoot: true 

  • Defines this entity as the root node of the Business Object. Other nodes (child entities) can be linked to it via composition relationships. 

transactionalProcessingEnabled: true 

  • Enables transactional behavior (create, update, delete, save, rollback) for the entity, making it suitable for business object processing. 

writeActivePersistence: 'ZKK_dt_travel' 

  • Specifies the database table (ZKK_DT_TRAVEL) where the active (persisted) data of this entity is stored. 

createEnabled: true 

  • Allows the creation of new records in the entity. 

updateEnabled: true 

  • Allows modification of existing records. 

deleteEnabled: true 

  • Allows deletion of records. 

@odata.publish: true    turns your CDS view into an OData service provider, making its data available for consumption via OData protocols. 

In short: 

This annotation block is used to define a CDS entity as a Business Object root node with full CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) support and persistence in the custom table ZKK_DT_TRAVEL. 

Here I am creating the Metadata extension for the Basic view (ZI_KK_TRAVEL) for consuming it in the front end. 

@Metadata.layer: #CORE
@UI.headerInfo: {
    typeName: 'Travel',
    typeNamePlural: 'Travel Details'
}
annotate entity zi_kk_travel
    with 
{
@UI.facet: [{ 
id: 'Travel', 
purpose: #STANDARD, 
position: 10, 
label: 'Travel Details ', 
type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE 
} ]
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 10, label: 'Travel Id' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 10 }]
    travel_id;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 20, label: 'Email' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 20 }]
    user_email;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 30, label: 'Travel Date' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 30 }]
    start_date;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 40, label: 'Destination' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 40 }]
    destination;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 50, label: 'Status' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 50 }]
    status;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 60, label: 'Expense Type' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 60 }]
    expense_type;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 65, label: 'Amount' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 65 }]
    total_cost;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 70, label: 'Currency' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 70 }]
    curr_key;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 80, label: 'Remarks for Expense' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 80 }]
    remarks;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 85, label: 'Created By' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 10 }]
    created_by;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 90, label: 'Created Date' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 90 }]
    created_on;   
}

 Now activate the Basic view and the meta data extension, when it gets activated the Business Object get created implicitly. 

Now open the BOBX Transaction. 

We can search the business object in Home business objects or click on the below marked option.

Provide the BO name which is our Basic View name (ZI_KK_TRAVEL) 

Now to Implement the validations expand the Node Elements  

Right Click on Validations will see the option to Create Validations 

Provide the Validation Name and Description and Class for implementing the validation logic. 

Double click on Class Name, and create a class which will be having the super class implicitly 

Now we have to provide Triggering conditions for the validations, so select the Node instance and tick on Create, Update, Delete and Check  

Save it and check and generate it. 

After this we have to go to eclipse and create a service definition on basic view (ZI_KK_TRAVEL) 

Now create a Service binding on top of Service definition and publish it  

When we preview it  

It will be navigated to the frontend while navigating it will ask for your SAP GUI Credentials to login.

Now go to SE91 Transaction and create a message class

Here, I am doing Validation for a Single status field only so i have passed only two messages  

Now I want to provide the Validations for Status field, so go to our class which we have created in Validations 

Implement our Custom login in this method.

  METHOD /bobf/if_frw_validation~execute.

    CLEAR : et_failed_key, eo_message.
    eo_message = /bobf/cl_frw_factory=>get_message( ).
    DATA : lt_data TYPE ztikk_travel,   " Table type for header node
           ls_msg  TYPE symsg.
    io_read->retrieve(
      EXPORTING
        iv_node                 = is_ctx-node_key
        it_key                  = it_key
        iv_fill_data            = abap_true
        it_requested_attributes = VALUE #(
                                          (                 zif_i_kk_travel_c=>sc_node_attribute-zi_kk_travel-status )
                                         ) )
      IMPORTING
        et_data                 = lt_data
    ).
    LOOP AT lt_data REFERENCE INTO DATA(ls_data).
      IF ls_data->status IS INITIAL .
        ls_msg-msgid = 'ZKK_MSG_BOPF'.
        ls_msg-msgno = '000'.
        ls_msg-msgty = 'E'.

        eo_message->add_message(
          is_msg       = ls_msg                 " Message that is to be added to the message object
          iv_node      = is_ctx-node_key            " Node to be used in the origin location
          iv_key       = ls_data->key            " Instance key to be used in the origin location
iv_attribute = zif_i_kk_travel_c=>sc_node_attribute-zi_kk_travel-status
          " Attribute to be used in the origin location
        ).

        INSERT VALUE #( key = ls_data->key ) INTO TABLE et_failed_key.
      ENDIF.

      DATA(lv_status) = to_upper( condense( ls_data->status ) ).
      IF lv_status NA 'ACCEPT' OR lv_status NA 'REJECT'.
        ls_msg-msgid = 'ZKK_MSG_BOPF'.
        ls_msg-msgno = '001'.
        ls_msg-msgty = 'E'.

        eo_message->add_message(
          is_msg       = ls_msg
          iv_node      = is_ctx-node_key
          iv_key       = ls_data->key
          iv_attribute = zif_i_kk_travel_c=>sc_node_attribute-zi_kk_travel-status
        ).

        INSERT VALUE #( key = ls_data->key ) INTO TABLE et_failed_key.
      ENDIF.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.

Now go to service binding and preview it. Try to create a new record. 

Here I am keeping Status field as empty so it will throw error. 

Now Status should accept only ‘ACCEPT’ or ‘REJECT’. If I try to give any other value it will throw error again. 

If you give the correct value ‘Accept’ or ‘Reject’. 

Conclusion

Validations in BOPF play a vital role in safeguarding data quality and enforcing business rules at the framework level. By defining validations directly on the business object nodes, we ensure that only consistent and compliant data enters the system, regardless of whether it originates from an SAP UI, an external interface, or a background process. This not only strengthens the reliability of the application but also reduces the need for redundant checks across different layers. In short, validations serve as a powerful and centralized mechanism to guarantee data integrity within the BOPF model.

entry.title: Step-by-Step Guide to Creating a Custom Business Object in BOPF
entry.content:
Introduction 

The Business Object Processing Framework (BOPF) is an SAP framework that simplifies the development of business objects by providing a standardized way to handle data persistence, business logic, validations, determinations, and actions. Instead of writing custom code for every use case, developers can rely on BOPF’s reusable building blocks, ensuring consistency and reducing development effort. 

In this guide, we will walk through the step-by-step process of creating a custom Business Object in BOPF. Starting with the creation of dictionary elements, moving through defining the root node and generating dictionary artifacts in transaction BOBX, and finally testing our object in BOBT, you’ll gain a clear understanding of how to set up and validate your first custom BO. 

Steps to Create a Custom Business Object 
Create the Business Object in BOBX 
Go to transaction BOBX. 
Click on the Create menu option. 
Enter the Business Object name and description. 
In the Properties section, select Business Object. 

 

Define the Root Node 
Click on ROOT. 
Provide the following: 
Data Structure 
Combined Structure 
Combined Table Type 
Database Table Name 
Click Save. 
Double-click on the database table name. If it does not exist, create it explicitly in SE11.  

Generate Dictionary Elements 
Once the database table is created, return to BOBX. 
Navigate to Extras → Generate Dictionary Elements. 
This will automatically generate the required structures and table types.

Check and Generate 
Run Check and Correct in BOBX to validate your business object. 
Once validation is successful, click on the Generate button. 
The system generates the BOPF repository objects for your Business Object. 

Test the Business Object in BOBT 
Go to transaction BOBT. 
Select your custom Business Object. 
Perform test operations such as Create, Update, and Delete. 
Verify that the database entries are updated correctly. 

 

Conclusion: 

By following the steps outlined in this guide, you can successfully create, configure, and test a custom Business Object in BOPF. Using BOBX for modeling and generation and BOBT for testing, you gain hands-on experience with one of the most powerful frameworks in SAP for managing business data and logic. 

BOPF not only reduces manual coding but also enforces a structured, model-driven development approach, making your applications easier to maintain and extend. Once you are comfortable with creating root nodes and dictionary elements, you can explore advanced topics such as actions, determinations, validations, and associations to implement complete business processes.

entry.title: SAP Business ByDesign: Automatic Payment Allocation via Bank Statement SOAP API
entry.content:
Issue Summary
When uploading a Bank Statement via SOAP API with Posted status, the system creates Payment Allocation tasks instead of automatically allocating payments to supplier invoices. I want to achieve automatic payment allocation through the SOAP API without manual intervention.


Current Situation
What I've Done:

entry.title: Working with Internal Tables, Parallel cursor, Control Break Statements, Messages
entry.content:
Working with internal Tables

Below topics we are going to discuss in detail

1.Types of Internal Tables

2.Creating Internal Tables

3.Populating and Processing Internal Tables

4.Usage of work area and Field-symbol

5.Data manipulation in Internal table

6.Parallel Cursor usage

7.Control Break Statements

8.Messages

 

1. Types of Internal Tables

In SAP ABAP (Advanced Business Application Programming), Internal tables are used to store temporary data during program execution.

There are three main types of internal tables in SAP:

  • Standard Internal Table
  • Sorted Internal Table
  • Hashed Internal Table

Standard Internal Table

This is default internal table type.

In Standard internal table, Table entries are stored in the order they are inserted.

  • Standard internal table are not sorted automatically. We have to use the SORT statement for sorting the table entries based on keys.
  • Standard internal table follows Linear search process for searching the records 
  • Here passing of data from work area to internal table is through APPEND keyword.
  • Standard internal table is not recommended for large datasets
  • Standard internal table accepts duplicate entries unless explicitly defined with a unique key.
  • Standard internal table is accessed by using index or key

Usage: Standard internal table is recommended only when sequence of fields are mattered or dealing with small datasets.

Example :  DATA: lt_standard TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF mara.

Sorted Internal Table

Sorted internal table entries are automatically sorted based on a defined key.

  • Sorted internal table follows binary search process for searching of records
  • Here passing of data from work area to internal table is through INSERT keyword.
  • Can enforce unique keys or allow duplicates depending on declaration
  • Here we must specify at least one field as unique or non-unique
  • Cannot manually sort or insert at a specific position.
  • Sorted internal table is accessed by using index or key

Usage: Sorted internal table is recommended for reading the entries based on keys

Example: DATA: lt_sorted TYPE SORTED TABLE OF mara WITH UNIQUE KEY matnr.

Hashed Internal Table

Hashed internal table uses a hashed algorithm for key-based access.

  • Hashed internal table follows Hashed Algorithm for searching of single record
  • Here passing of data from work area to internal table is through COLLECT keyword.
  • Fastest access for reading single entries using keys.
  • It does not accept duplicate records.
  • Only allows unique keys.
  • Hashed internal table is accessed by using key only

Usage: Hashed internal table is recommended for reading single entry from table by using key

Example: DATA: lt_hashed TYPE HASHED TABLE OF mara WITH UNIQUE KEY matnr.

Decision Framework of Standard/ Sorted / Hashed Internal Tables

2. Creating Internal Tables

Examples for creating Internal tables with type declarations and using standard table

3. Populating and processing Internal Table

Example1: Standard table  Example with Reading data from table MARA (General Article Data)

Example 2 : Appending the data to Internal table  and display.

Example 3 : Sorted table data display

a

Example 4: Hashed table  data display

4. Usage of Work area and Field Symbol

Example on using work area

Result: 

Example on Field-symbol

 

Result

5. Data manipulation in Internal Table

Result 

6.Parallel Cursor

Parallel cursor is a performance optimization technique used primarily to enhance the efficiency of programs involving nested loops, especially when dealing with large internal tables.

Improve the performance of program.

Decreases the CPU and memory consumption associated with extensive loop iterations.

7.Control Break Statements

Control break statements are events inside the loop statement.

There are 5 control break statements in ABAP.

They are used within loop.(Except ON CHANGE OF which can be used outside the loop as well)

AT FIRST - ENDAT

AT NEW - ENDAT

AT END OF - ENDAT

AT LAST - ENDAT

ON CHANGE OF

AT FIRST: Will trigger at the first run of the loop.

AT LAST: Will trigger at the last run of the loop.

The below 3 events are normally used when the table is sorted.

AT END OF : When we use At end for a field, it will trigger whenever there is any change in any of the fields from the left to that of the particular field. The trigger point will be the at the last occurrence  of the same value for the field.

AT NEW: When we use At new for a field, it will trigger whenever there is any change in any of the fields from the left to that of the particular field.The trigger point will be the at the first occurrence of the new value for the field.

ON CHANGE OF: On change of it triggers only when there is any change in the particular field.

On change of can be used outside the loop too

Example code on Control Break Statements

 

 

8. Messages

  • In classical ABAP reports, messages are used to communicate information, warnings, errors, or success statuses to the user. 
  • These messages are typically displayed on the screen or in the status bar, and their behaviour depends on the message type.
  • Message Types in ABAP
    1. Success - Type S - Displays the status of the program. ( Success message)
    2. Error - Type E - An error message appears and the program stops. 
    3. Information - Type I -  The program is executed and information message  is displayed
    4. Warning - Type W - This is used to display warning information for the user, but they don’t stop the program
    5. Exit - Type X - The program terminates and the detailed information can be found in transaction ST22
    6. Abort - Type  A - The message appears in a dialog box and the program terminates.

Success Message:

Syntax : MESSAGE 'Success message: Operation successful!' TYPE ’S'.

Output : 

Information Message

Syntax:      MESSAGE 'Informational message.' TYPE ‘I'.

Output:

 

Warning Message: 

Syntax: MESSAGE 'Warning message: Data inconsistent' TYPE ‘W'.

Output

 

Syntax: MESSAGE 'Warning message: Data inconsistent' TYPE 'W' DISPLAY LIKE ‘I'.

 

Error Message:

Syntax:  MESSAGE 'Error Message: An error occurred during processing.' TYPE ‘E'.

Output

Abort Message

Syntax: MESSAGE 'Abort Message:  Program terminated due to critical error.' TYPE 'A'.

Output:

Exit Message

Syntax:  MESSAGE 'Exit Message: Critical error encountered!' TYPE 'X'.

Output:

Creating Message through text messages in report

  • SE38—> In Menu bar select  GOTO —> Select text symbols —> enter text name

     

Code: Message text-001 type 'S'.

Output: 

 

Thanks!!
